BRIDGES OF UNDERSTANDING
“More people live in Asia, in closer
contact, than anywhere else in the
world. By virtue of their numbers alone
they constitute a rich resource for the
rest of the world. Their capacity for
growth is enormous. Their capacity to
contribute either destructively or con¬
structively cannot yet be even dimly
perceived. Their capacity to cooperate
on world problems will, l am positive,
be stupendous.
uTherefore, in the particular and of
course unique period in history in
which I live and in which l contem¬
plate the probable history of my nation
and the world, 1 am more inclined than
l would have been at any previous time
in history to build bridges of under¬
standing between America and Asia. I
never forget that in this interchange
America is in a strong position to give
Asia much; but the longer l live in Asia
the more convinced l am that this great
continent can also give us much.”
-James A. Michener
